quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 13 Quiz 4
quiz.subtitle: 13.4: Decay Kinetics
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Half-life, decay constants, and activity calculations

questions.question: Radioactive decay follows which type of reaction kinetics?
questions.explanation: The rate of decay is proportional to the number of radioactive nuclei present: $Rate = \lambda N$.

questions.question: What is the relationship between the decay constant ($\lambda$) and half-life ($t_{1/2}$)?
questions.explanation: Half-life and the decay constant are inversely proportional, derived from $\ln(2) / \lambda$.

questions.question: If an isotope has a half-life of 10 minutes, what fraction of the original sample remains after 30 minutes?
The 'activity' of a radioactive sample is defined as:
options: The number of disintegrations per unit time.
The total mass of the sample.
The energy released per alpha particle.
The time required for the sample to become safe.
questions.explanation: Activity (A) is the rate of decay, often measured in Becquerels (Bq) or Curies (Ci).

questions.question: Which of the following factors will increase the rate constant of a radioactive decay process?
questions.explanation: Nuclear decay is a spontaneous process independent of external physical or chemical conditions.

questions.question: A sample of Iodine-131 ($t_{1/2} = 8$ days) has an initial activity of 1000 Bq. What is the activity after 16 days?
If the decay constant $\lambda$ is $0.01\ s^{-1}$, what is the half-life of the isotope?
The SI unit for radioactivity, representing one decay per second, is the:
questions.explanation: 1 Bq = 1 disintegration per second. The Curie is a non-SI unit equal to $3.7 \times 10^{10}$ Bq.

questions.question: After 5 half-lives, approximately what percentage of a radioactive isotope has decayed?
Which equation is used to calculate the remaining amount of a substance ($N$) at time $t$?
questions.explanation: This is the integrated rate law for first-order decay.

scoreMessages.70: Good job. You can handle half-life cycles.
